name: Bigtable
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Bigtable.

google-cloud is deprecated

Due to the scope of our API rapidly increasing, you may notice a decrease in performance if you continue to use the bundled module, google-cloud.

Going forward, please install only the individual service modules that you need, such as @google-cloud/bigtable.

The instructions below are here for reference, however, we will soon stop releasing updates to the bundled package.

First, install google-cloud with npm:

$ npm install --save google-cloud

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to google-cloudâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var bigtable = gcloud.bigtable();

Elsewhere

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var bigtable = gcloud.bigtable({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to google-cloud are outlined in our Authentication guide.

examples.caption:
The Bigtable Emulator

Make sure you have the gcloud SDK installed, then run: 
 
$ gcloud beta emulators bigtable start
Before running your Node.js app, set the environment variables that this library will look for to connect to the emulator: 
 
$ $(gcloud beta emulators bigtable env-init)

Creating a Bigtable Instance and Cluster

Before you create your table, you first need to create a Bigtable Instance and cluster for the table to be served from.
This can also be done from either the Google Cloud Platform Console or the gcloud cli tool. Please refer to the official Bigtable documentation for more information.

Creating Tables

After creating your instance and enabling the Bigtable APIs, you are now ready to create your table with bigtable/instance#createTable.

Creating Column Families

Column families are used to group together various pieces of data within your table. You can think of column families as a mechanism to categorize all of your data. We can create a column family with bigtable/table#createFamily.
It is also possible to create your column families when creating a new table.

Creating Rows

New rows can be created within your table using bigtable/table#insert. You must provide a unique key for each row to be inserted, this key can then be used to retrieve your row at a later time. With Bigtable, all columns have a unique id composed of a column family and a column qualifier. In the example below follows is the column family and tjefferson is the column qualifier. Together they could be referred to as follows:tjefferson.

Retrieving Rows

If you're anticipating a large number of rows to be returned, we suggest using the bigtable/table#getRows streaming API.
If you're not anticpating a large number of results, a callback mode is also available.
A range of rows can be retrieved by providing start and end row keys.
Retrieve an individual row with bigtable/row#get.

Accessing Row Data

When retrieving rows, upon success the row.data property will be populated by an object. That object will contain additional objects for each family in your table that the row has data for. By default, when retrieving rows, each column qualifier will provide you with all previous versions of the data. So your row.data object could resemble the following. { follows: { wmckinley: [ { value: 1, timestamp: 1466017315951 }, { value: 2, timestamp: 1458619200000 } ] } }

The timestamp field can be used to order cells from newest to oldest. If you only wish to retrieve the most recent version of the data, you can specify the number of cells with a bigtable/filter object.

Deleting Row Data

We can delete all of an individual row's cells using bigtable/row#delete.
To delete a specific set of cells, we can provide an array of column families and qualifiers.

Deleting Rows

If you wish to delete multiple rows entirely, we can do so with bigtable/table#deleteRows. You can provide this method with a row key prefix.
If you omit the prefix, you can delete all rows in your table.

params.name: options.apiEndpoint
params.description: • Override the default API endpoint used to reach Bigtable. This is useful for connecting to your local Bigtable emulator.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options.clusters
params.description: • The clusters to be created within the instance.

params.name: options.displayName
params.description: • The descriptive name for this instance as it appears in UIs.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.operation
params.description: • An operation object that can be used to check the status of the request.

methods.name: getInstances
methods.description: Get Instance objects for all of your Compute instances.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: query.maxApiCalls
params.description: • Maximum number of API calls to make.

params.name: query.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: callback.error
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: getInstancesStream
methods.description: Get bigtable/instance objects for all of your Compute instances as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query
params.description: • Configuration object. See bigtable#getInstances for a complete list of options.

methods.name: instance
methods.description: Get a reference to a Compute instance.
